title: 112_hr198
content: The "Veterans Dog Training Therapy Act" establishes a Department of Veterans Affairs pilot program on dog training therapy. The Department of Veterans Affairs will conduct a pilot program to assess the effectiveness of using service dogs to help veterans with post-deployment mental health issues and PTSD. The program will run for 5 years at 3-5 VA medical centers, providing training areas for veterans to learn how to train and handle service dogs. The areas will include indoor grooming and training spaces, wheelchair accessibility, and classroom facilities. The pilot program aims to educate veterans with mental health conditions in service dog training. It includes dedicated indoor spaces for grooming and training, wheelchair accessibility, classroom facilities, office space, equipment storage, outdoor exercise areas, and transportation for field trips. The program will be administered by the Recreation Therapy Service of the Department of Veterans Affairs under the direction of a certified recreational therapist. In the pilot program, the Secretary will oversee the administration through the Recreation Therapy Service, establish a director of service dog training, ensure certified instructors at each site, and consider dogs from shelters or foster homes for training. The pilot program for veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder will have certified service dog training instructors, consider dogs from shelters or foster homes, teach essential commands, have dogs live at the training site, include hands-on training, and maximize therapeutic benefits. The pilot program for veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder includes lecture and hands-on training of service dogs to maximize therapeutic benefits and provide well-trained service dogs to veterans with disabilities. Veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder or other post-deployment mental health conditions can volunteer if resources are available, and hiring preference for service dog training instructors is given to veterans who have graduated from residential treatment programs. The Department of Veterans Affairs offers a work therapy program. Hiring preference for service dog training instructors is given to veterans who have graduated from residential treatment programs. The Secretary collects data on the pilot program to assess its effectiveness in assisting veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder. Data includes reducing stigma, improving emotional regulation, patience, sense of purpose, community reintegration, and reducing social isolation. The pilot program aims to assist veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder by improving emotional regulation, patience, sense of purpose, community reintegration, relationship skills, sleep patterns, and reducing the use of pain medication. Reports to Congress on the program's effectiveness are required annually. The report to Congress on the pilot program for veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder must include the number of participants, services provided, effects on symptoms and well-being, and recommendations for program extension or expansion. The report to Congress on the pilot program for veterans with post-traumatic stress disorder should include the number of participants, services provided, effects on symptoms, recommendations for program extension or expansion, insomnia and pain management, overall well-being, and service dog training instructor definition.
